title: How to Configure a Laptop to a Wireless Router

steps.title: Click the Wi-Fi icon.
steps.content: Click the Wi-Fi icon. It's the series of curving lines in the far-right side of the task bar. You may first have to click the ^ to the left of the volume or battery icon to see the Wi-Fi option. On Windows 7, the Wi-Fi icon looks like a series of increasingly tall bars.

steps.title: Click your router's network name.
steps.content: Click your router's network name. If you set up the router with a specific name, it should appear here. If you didn't set up a specific name, you should see the router's brand (e.g., "Linksys") and model number.

steps.title: Click Connect.
steps.content: Click Connect . It's in the bottom-right side of the Wi-Fi network's name card.

steps.title: Enter the network's password.
steps.content: Enter the network's password. You'll do this in the text box below the "Enter the network's security key" heading. If you didn't add a password to your network when setting up the router, the password (called a "Security Key") is on the back or bottom of the router unit.

steps.title: Click Next.
steps.content: Click Next . As long as the password is correct, doing so will connect you to the router's wireless signal.

steps.title: Select a network privacy option.
steps.content: Select a network privacy option. Choosing Yes will allow other devices on the network to find and request access to your computer, while clicking No will hide your computer in the network. If you're using a home network, you can typically choose Yes without suffering any negative repercussions.

steps.title: Click the Wi-Fi icon.
steps.content: Click the Wi-Fi icon. It's a series of curving lines in the top-right side of the menu bar. Clicking it will invoke a drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click your router's network name.
steps.content: Click your router's network name. If you assigned a name to your router when setting it up, the name will appear here; otherwise, look for your router's brand and/or model number. For example, you might see "Cisco" and a series of numbers and letters for a Cisco router.

steps.title: Enter the password.
steps.content: Enter the password. You'll do so in the text field to the right of the "Password" heading. If you didn't add a password to your network when setting up the router, the password (called a "Security Key") is on the back or bottom of the router unit. You can also check the "Remember this network" box to sign into this network automatically whenever you're in range.

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . As long as your password is correct, this will connect your Mac to the wireless router.

steps.title: Click the Wi-Fi icon.
steps.content: Click the Wi-Fi icon. It's a funnel-shaped icon in the bottom-right corner of the screen. If Wi-Fi is disabled, you'll need to enable it by clicking the Wi-Fi switch before continuing.

steps.title: Click your wireless network's name.
steps.content: Click your wireless network's name. This will be either the name you assigned to your wireless router, or a combination of the router's brand and model number.

steps.title: Enter the network's password.
steps.content: Enter the network's password. It goes in the text field that's in the Wi-Fi menu. If you didn't add a password to your network when setting up the router, the password (called a "Security Key") is on the back or bottom of the router unit.

steps.title: Click Connect.
steps.content: Click Connect . As long as your password is correct, doing so will connect your Chromebook to the wireless router.
